intro: Braya purpurascens var. thorild-wulffii, commonly known as the purple saxifrage, is a flowering plant native to Arctic and alpine regions. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and hairy, fleshy leaves adapted to cold climates. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is well-suited to harsh environmental conditions. Its flowers are usually pink or purple, and it blooms during the short growing season in polar and high-altitude areas. This variant is distinguished by its specific geographic distribution and morphological traits compared to other braya species.
